content: >http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5iAKhXQV6M31ixUatPPRlVplIhP0g The Warren (Pa) Times Observer apologized after it mistakenly ran a classified ad expressing the wish that the current President 'join Lincoln, Garfield, McKinley and Kennedy' the four presidents of the US who were assassinated. The staff didn't make the 'historical connection', before publishing the personal advertisement reflecting an attitude "all too prevalent in Pennsylvania".
reply: >http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5iAKhXQV6M31ixUatPPRlVplIhP0g The Warren (Pa) Times Observer apologized after it mistakenly ran a classified ad expressing the wish that the current President 'join Lincoln, Garfield, McKinley and Kennedy' the four presidents of the US who were assassinated. content: quote: Originally posted by AliBubba: >http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5iAKhXQV6M31ixUatPPRlVplIhP0g The Warren (Pa) Times Observer apologized after it mistakenly ran a classified ad expressing the wish that the current President 'join Lincoln, Garfield, McKinley and Kennedy' the four presidents of the US who were assassinated. The staff didn't make the 'historical connection', before publishing the personal advertisement reflecting an attitude "all too prevalent in Pennsylvania". The really tragic part of this situation is that the staff probably had absolutely no clue who Garfield and McKinley were and at best only a vague awareness of Lincoln and Kennedy.

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Do our citizens as a whole really have that lousy of a knowledge of history? Seriously - there wasn't much worth noting in the Presidencies of Garfield and McKinley other than that they were assasinated........... Have you ever seen the Jay Leno segment entitled "Jaywalking" in which he asks randomly selected individuals questions about American history/society. On the one hand the results are hilarious while on the other they are truly troubling. One guy literally did not know who wrote The Autobiography of Malcolm X, he went on to answer that his own autobiography would be written by a friend. Perhaps it just a function of population growth, but the number of truly ignorant people seems to be increasing.

content: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?
reply: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?
title: Pa Newspaper Apologizes for Obama Ad

Sure people would notice, we would trust the government more if Spongebob were in charge. He always does the right thing, even if it is accidental.

title: Pa Newspaper Apologizes for Obama Ad

content: quote: Originally posted by iamgonzo: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote? It is every American's right to vote, even if they do not have a clue. Denying someone the right to vote because they do not pay attention to current events or did not get a passing grade in their US Government class is about as unconstitutional as it gets. If you feel that people who are "uneducated" in the political process are a hindrance to that process then do something about it. Volunteer as a canvasser for one of the candidates during the next election.
quote: Originally posted by iamgonzo: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?
reply: It is every American's right to vote, even if they do not have a clue. Denying someone the right to vote because they do not pay attention to current events or did not get a passing grade in their US Government class is about as unconstitutional as it gets. If you feel that people who are "uneducated" in the political process are a hindrance to that process then do something about it. Volunteer as a canvasser for one of the candidates during the next election.

The staff didn't make the 'historical connection', before publishing the personal advertisement reflecting an attitude "all too prevalent in Pennsylvania".

content: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?
reply: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?

content: quote: Originally posted by BAGodbehere: Shuman,,,Sponge Bob Square Pants lives under the pinapple, Obama lives at 1600 Penn Ave. I think it could be reversed and no one would notice. Sure people would notice, we would trust the government more if Spongebob were in charge. He always does the right thing, even if it is accidental.

title: Pa Newspaper Apologizes for Obama Ad

content: quote: Originally posted by iamgonzo: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote? It is every American's right to vote, even if they do not have a clue. Denying someone the right to vote because they do not pay attention to current events or did not get a passing grade in their US Government class is about as unconstitutional as it gets. If you feel that people who are "uneducated" in the political process are a hindrance to that process then do something about it. Volunteer as a canvasser for one of the candidates during the next election.
quote: Originally posted by iamgonzo: This is exactly why I believe there should be a test you have to pass to vote. Nothing real difficult. Just what type of government do we have? How many branches does the federal government have? Name them. How many presidents have there been? How long is the president's term? Congressman's term? Senator's term? How many Senators are there? I wouldn't even mind if people were to say the three branches were the Presidential, Congressional, and Courts instead of the actual names. Just want to know if they have a clue. If you don't even have a clue how can you cast an informed vote?
reply: It is every American's right to vote, even if they do not have a clue. Denying someone the right to vote because they do not pay attention to current events or did not get a passing grade in their US Government class is about as unconstitutional as it gets. If you feel that people who are "uneducated" in the political process are a hindrance to that process then do something about it. Volunteer as a canvasser for one of the candidates during the next election.

content: quote: Originally posted by stec74: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Do our citizens as a whole really have that lousy of a knowledge of history? Seriously - there wasn't much worth noting in the Presidencies of Garfield and McKinley other than that they were assasinated........... Have you ever seen the Jay Leno segment entitled "Jaywalking" in which he asks randomly selected individuals questions about American history/society. On the one hand the results are hilarious while on the other they are truly troubling. One guy literally did not know who wrote The Autobiography of Malcolm X, he went on to answer that his own autobiography would be written by a friend. Perhaps it just a function of population growth, but the number of truly ignorant people seems to be increasing. Welcome to a society that rewards mediocrity. It's worse than that; it's the norm, a societal expectation that the media is more than happy to endorse and build its programs around.
quote: Originally posted by stec74: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Do our citizens as a whole really have that lousy of a knowledge of history? Seriously - there wasn't much worth noting in the Presidencies of Garfield and McKinley other than that they were assasinated........... On the one hand the results are hilarious while on the other they are truly troubling. One guy literally did not know who wrote The Autobiography of Malcolm X, he went on to answer that his own autobiography would be written by a friend. Perhaps it just a function of population growth, but the number of truly ignorant people seems to be increasing. Welcome to a society that rewards mediocrity.
reply: It's worse than that; it's the norm, a societal expectation that the media is more than happy to endorse and build its programs around.
